descriptions.title: Overview
descriptions.content: A creative etymology, at times called a folk etymology, is rooted in specific literary or oral commentaries on a word which creatively link the sounds or meanings of the underlying syllables of a multisyllabic term with a specific meaning they want to emphasize for the word overall.  Such "creative etymologies" are often spurious in terms of their analysis of the syllables, and use false associations such as homonymic links that are not in any way accurate. However the practice of providing such creative etymologies is pervasive in Tibetan literature, and thus it is very important to document them. They contrast to "basic syllabic etymology" which is an attempt to provide a pragmatic account of the syllables meanings and their relationship to the term's overall meaning outside of any specific interpretative angle,  or "historical etymology", which focuses on a linguistic scholarly analysis of the word's linguistic roots.
